site_name: Carson Springs Wildlife Conservation Foundation County

citations.narrative:
During certain times of the year, the facility has guest interactions that allow the public to come in contact with their
animals, including the lemurs and a kinkajou. The facility confirmed that during these public interactions, the lemurs and
kinkajou were allowed to sit on the heads and shoulders of guests and come into close contact with their faces and
mouths.
Allowing nonhuman primates and other animals to sit on the heads and shoulders of guests and come in close contact
with their faces increases the likelihood of injury and the spread of zoonotic disease. During public exhibition, any animal
must be handled so there is minimal risk of harm to the animal and to the public.
To be corrected by February 24, 2025.

In two of the spotted hyena enclosures, the corrugated metal and wooden roof has been damaged by the animal. This
has created sharp metal edges and exposed the tips of screws.
In the enclosure housing six red river hogs, there are metal wire panels surrounding multiple tree bases that are
damaged. This crumpled wire has sharp points and multiple loops of wire sticking out where the animals can access it.
Enclosures that are not kept in good repair can result in injury from sharp points or entrapment. The facility must be
constructed of such material and of such strength as appropriate for the animals involved. The housing facilities shall be
maintained in good repair to protect the animals from injury and to contain the animals.
To be corrected by March 3, 2025.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
n

narrative:
2.131(c)(1) 
   
Handling of animals. 
During certain times of the year, the facility has guest interactions that allow the public to come in contact with their 
animals, including the lemurs and a kinkajou. The facility confirmed that during these public interactions, the lemurs and 
kinkajou were allowed to sit on the heads and shoulders of guests and come into close contact with their faces and 
mouths.  
Allowing nonhuman primates and other animals to sit on the heads and shoulders of guests and come in close contact 
with their faces increases the likelihood of injury and the spread of zoonotic disease. During public exhibition, any animal 
must be handled so there is minimal risk of harm to the animal and to the public.  
To be corrected by February 24, 2025. 
3.125(a) 
   
Facilities, general. 
In two of the spotted hyena enclosures, the corrugated metal and wooden roof has been damaged by the animal. This 
has created sharp metal edges and exposed the tips of screws.  
In the enclosure housing six red river hogs, there are metal wire panels surrounding multiple tree bases that are 
damaged. This crumpled wire has sharp points and multiple loops of wire sticking out where the animals can access it.  
Enclosures that are not kept in good repair can result in injury from sharp points or entrapment. The facility must be 
constructed of such material and of such strength as appropriate for the animals involved. The housing facilities shall be 
maintained in good repair to protect the animals from injury and to contain the animals. 
To be corrected by March 3, 2025. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative. 
 
 n

species.common: DOMESTIC PIG / POTBELLY PIG / MICRO PIG
